Headline.Para: Beer Twins (One Evil) Take Feud to Queens

LeadPara.Para: Mikkel Borg Bjergso and Jeppe Jarnit-Bjergso are 42-year-old identical twins from Niva, Denmark, a small town outside Copenhagen. They were close growing up, but they haven't spent time together and have hardly spoken since 2010. That was when Jeppe, who lives in Brooklyn, launched Evil Twin Brewing, a craft beer company that would challenge the one his brother had started in 2006 named Mikkeller.

Since then both companies have risen toward the top of the beer world. Mikkel, who is based in Copenhagen, focuses on opening quirky bars around the world to sell his experimental brews straight to fans.

TailParas.Para: Jeppe's Evil Twin distributes a smaller selection of beers to over 35 countries around the world. He has never owned a physical space outright, although for a while his wife, Maria Jarnit-Bjergso, owned Torst, a bar and restaurant in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, known for pairing Evil Twin selections with its dishes.

Now, seemingly without consulting each other, the Bjergso brothers have embarked on practically the same next step in expanding their beer empires: They are both opening breweries and taprooms in Queens. The operations -- both at about 10,000 square feet (Evil Twin will have an additional 5,000 square-foot outdoor space) -- are scheduled to open months apart.

It is a momentous occasion for both brothers, who have historically been gypsy brewers, meaning that they have rented space in other breweries to make their niche beers. This is the third brewery Mikkeller has opened (but only its second large-scale operation). It is Evil Twin's first.

''I think it's great that both brands are coming to a city that needs more great beer,'' said Andrew Burman, co-founder of Other Half Brewing in Brooklyn. ''These guys both started off as gypsy breweries, and they are the ones that made a whole range of breweries possible.'' Mr. Burman cited the young company Root + Branch, currently establishing itself on Long Island's South Shore, as a business directly inspired by the Bjergso brothers.

On March 25, Mikkeller Brewing NYC is scheduled to open in an industrial space inside Citi Field, home of the New York Mets. There will be concrete floors, 30-foot-high-ceilings, white birch furniture, hand-drawn murals and exposed steel beams.

Mikkel operates his bars from Copenhagen, appointing or partnering with people to oversee the locations. ''I don't know a lot about baseball, but I've been to some games, and I sense there is beer drinking going on, but it's a different kind of beer drinking,'' Mikkel said in a phone interview. ''If we can turn Budweiser drinkers into craft-beer drinkers, that would be great.''

His brewery at Citi Field intends to do just that. The Mikkeller NYC beers will incorporate unusual local ingredients, like Parlor coffee roasted in Brooklyn Navy Yard. There will also be a series of imperial I.P.A.s named Chop Shop, inspired by the automotive and muffler shops that used to fill the neighborhood around Citi Field. The beers will only be available in New York state.

A few neighborhoods south, in Ridgewood, will be Jeppe's new space, Evil Twin Brewing NYC, expected to open in July. Several small craft breweries already exist there, like Queens Brewery and Bridge and Tunnel. But Jeppe is looking to do something more over-the-top: He has acquired an old ballroom with saloon-style bathroom doors, heavy drapes and disco balls. ''When we saw it it was like a party had been suspended,'' Ms. Jarnit-Bjergso said.

A construction team is busy retrofitting the venue into Jeppe's dream brewery. The courtyard, enclosed by a pastel pink wall, will become a year-round greenhouse and seating area. A side area is being turned into a barrel room where beer will be aged in wine and bourbon vessels. There, the original sign from ''Twin Peaks,'' the noir television series, will be on display. ''When people are in here drinking, it will be good for them to have something to look at,'' said Jeppe.

Jeppe visits the brewery, which is still under construction, every day. ''I live two miles away and am involved in all the recipes,'' he said. Like Mikkeller, Evil Twin will also make beers specific to New York City.
Because the twins claim they don't communicate with each other, it's impossible to know whether their brewery openings are coincidental, acts of one-upmanship or clever public-relations stunts.

''I think it's nothing more than the fact that there are a lot of breweries coming up in New York,'' said Jim Raras Jr., the executive vice president of Mikkeller NYC. ''We happen to be one of them, and they happen to be another one.'' (Mikkel does not comment publicly about his brother.)
Jeppe, however, called the turn of events ''weird,'' and questioned his brother's motivations. ''He doesn't even live here,'' Jeppe said. ''He's only been here five times.''
Regardless of the timing, there are legitimate business reasons both brothers are interested in Queens.

In New York, especially in Queens, the beer industry is still underdeveloped, compared with the rest of the country. Even fashionable Brooklyn companies like Other Half and Threes Brewing only opened in 2014. ''Today we have now 25 brewers in New York, it's nothing,'' Jeppe said. ''San Diego has 150.''

Mikkel's view is similar. ''For such a big international city, it's kind of strange that there has been a lack of breweries until recently,'' he said. ''So it's an interesting time to do something young.'' He promises his Citi Field brewery will be something new. ''We'll do everything, we'll do crazy stuff,'' he said. ''It won't be boring. We'll give them the full range of what we are capable of.''

Jeppe chalks up the lack of brewery growth in the city to how expensive it is to operate a business here. ''But if you have success here?'' he said. ''They say if you can make it here, there is much more attention to what is happening here. The world pays attention.''

For Evil Twin, ready to give up the life of the gypsy brewer, building a headquarters in New York makes sense. ''We moved here six years ago to become New Yorkers,'' said Jeppe. ''We have become a New York brand, and this is the last step to that. We get emails every day from all over the world from people coming here on vacation and asking if they can visit something.'' People even knock on his home door asking for a tour because they think it's a brewery.

For Mikkeller, which has bars everywhere from Bangkok to the Faroe Islands, it is surprising that the company hasn't infiltrated the East Coast already, but Mikkel's ambitions for the region seem very clear.

''When I came to the U.S. and drank my own beers, I wasn't satisfied with them because they were never as fresh as I wanted them to be,'' Mikkel said. ''I kind of felt the American beer drinkers never drank it in the right way. We need to produce, present and serve beers exactly like we want to.''
Of course, none of those explanations address why both brothers -- who so far have kept their distance from each other -- are willing to be professional neighbors in Queens.
''The opportunity presented itself,'' said Mikkeller. ''We found out about space to rent that was exciting to us.''

Jeppe responded almost identically. ''In New York it's about finding the right space with the right lease,'' he said. With the old Ridgewood ballroom, so grand and so close to the subway, he explained, ''everything just seemed right.''
Industry insiders blame the coincidence on industry trends.

''Ten breweries have opened in Queens since 2011, so it's not a brand new phenomenon,'' said Mary Izett, who works for Long Island City's Fifth Hammer Brewing and serves as the secretary of the NYC Brewers Guild. ''I personally don't find it strange that two of them are owned by identical twins. Jeppe lives here, and New York City is a big craft beer market.'' She added that Queens has favorable zoning, lower real estate prices, and high neighborhood growth.

Sam Richardson, a founder and brewer at Other Half, knows both brothers. ''They are both very intelligent and hustle really hard, so they are both looking at New York as a great opportunity,'' he said. ''I think it's a logical step for just about anybody.''
In the close-knit New York brewing scene, Mr. Richardson predicted that both brothers would be welcomed into the fold.
''We all have separate relationships with each of them,'' he said. ''We can be friends personally, and we can be friends businesswise. We don't have to let all those things get tangled.''
That's a good thing, probably, because both brothers hinted, when asked by a reporter, that there might be more to come from them in New York.
''Let's do one first,'' said Jeppe.
''It's not planned,'' said Mikkel. ''But it's not out of the question.''
